comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: James Paul Clarke (1854-1916) was a United States Senator and the 18th Governor of Arkansas. He was born in Mississippi and graduated from the law department of the University of Virginia. He then practiced law in Helena, Arkansas. He married Miss Frances M. Moore of Helena in 1883. J.P. Clarke served the state of Arkansas as a member of the State house of representatives 1886-1888; member of the State senate 1888-1892, attorney general of Arkansas 1892-1894; and as Governor of Arkansas 1895-1896; Clarke, a/k/a "Old Cotton Top", was elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate in 1903, and served as President pro tempore of the Senate from 1913 to 1916. Last re-elected in November, 1914, he served the Senate for thirteen years until his death in 1916.  [1] [2] [3] For several years Senator Clarke was Chairman of the Committee on Commerce, and he was the ranking Democratic member of the Foreign Relations Committee. Senator Clarke was also the Chairman of the Committee on Disposition of Useless Executive Papers (1909-1913).
